first we need to understand why organizations are moving to cloud

of talk about things like IT efficiency capex to OPEX cost savings and they are

again is for that accelerated pace of business so then the critical thing with
security event is how do we address privacy compliance at the same scale of
the speed in the cloud so that we're protecting digital business but in a way that doesn't slow down this digital
transformation so we like to talk about security transformation so if digital
transformation is about the integration of digital technology into all areas of your business and security
transformation is the integration of security into all of that digital technology and doing it in a way that's both scaleable and transparent that can
be continuously improving and assessing your security posture so what is the
fundamental challenge with cloud security well it's really a matter of complexity so in the good old days we
had most of your server and other applications running in a one or a set
of on-premise data centers that were fully owned by your own internal IT and
all this may be accessed through a single access provider and you can put a lot of firewall or other in line
security with it but now as we go through the cloudy era a lot of your data centers themselves are transforming
into private clouds then you're migrating a lot of workloads in to AWS and the public cloud as well as you may
have other applications of data moving into SAS applications like say office 365 and you may also further be
leveraging some of your trusted service providers like they SingTel or star hub here in Singapore so all of this creates
you know a multi environment across many physical locations the way that those
are being accessed becomes more complex especially with a lot of the innovations at the new edge so things like direct
connects from your ax provider may connect your offices and campuses directly to the public cloud as well as
things like Sdn which also may and may further create additional paths for
your users to new sass and other applications so we can see that getting visibility and control of this broader
surface becomes much much more complex than when it was just a single set of data centers so the first thing we need
to understand about security in the cloud is that it's a shared responsibility so hopefully all of you
have heard of the concept of the shared security model a shared responsibility model it's a concept that's espouse not
only by AWS but also by most security vendors as well as leading industry
organizations like the cloud security Alliance and what it means is that when you have a public provider like AWS
providing key layers of your infrastructure like your compute networking and storage the service
provider is responsible for securing the layers that they provide so providing
the physical security so I know when it can access the hardware in the infrastructure providing a lot of
lockdown of the hypervisors and the compute and that infrastructure that
they're providing however you as the end customer or the tenant is still
responsible for securing the workloads that you bring over to the cloud so providing security for your ec2
instances for the the operating system security and the application security that's running within that instance also
providing some of the basic network security and access such as firewall to
those workloads now it doesn't mean that someone like AWS isn't providing some great tools like security groups or V
pcs that can assist with some of that segmentation but it's up to you as the as the tenant or the user to leverage
those capabilities and configure them properly to provide the right security configuration and security posture for
your workloads so there's still a lot of responsibility that falls onto you together with your your cloud provider
so let me talk about three key best practices as we look
migration to the cloud I'm going to talk about it in terms of 3 s's and the first
S stands for scale we need to scale protection particularly for elastic cloud workloads so once again if the key
goal of cloud computing is for accelerating the business it turns out a
lot of these applications are things like web or social applications to more
quickly connect with end-users customers patients etc and a lot of that activity
may grow very quickly and virally with user demand so you may have a lot of
workload traffic increasing very quickly so what you want to do is be able to of
course maintain security and privacy and and not lose the trust of these users but you need to do it in a way that
automatically scales that protection and the capacity to keep up with that greatly varying user demand as it scales
up and down you want to be able to automatically provision security protection to new instances and new
workloads as they spin out very quickly and automatically orchestrate the right
security and inspection with these workloads as they spin out the second S
then stands for a segment so we want us to be able to segment all our traffic both across clouds as well as within
each cloud so we want to do antenna and segmentation certainly as we're making
that migration workloads from across the hybrid cloud from on-premise the public cloud we want to make sure that we're
properly securing that traffic perhaps with a VPN as it migrates across but
also inspecting that traffic to make sure that the right data is is moving
and or not to the public cloud so in many cases organizations want to keep
more of the secure data on-premise and make sure that sensitive information doesn't move across to the to the public
cloud in some other instances I've seen actually some of the sensitive data is
actually residing in the public cloud such as PCI or credit card or transaction data and they don't want
that to migrate on Prime because that would increase the scope of audit subject to PCI compliance so
regardless of which way it's going you want to make sure that you're inspecting and making sure the right data is in the
right cloud then secondly within each cloud we want to make sure that we're properly segmenting workloads within the
private cloud and then very importantly within the public cloud with in AWS because as we migrate more and more
applications to the public cloud we don't want them all to be in a single flat network where if one server or
workload were to be compromised that a hacker could use that to now gain access to all of your servers and data so we
want to make sure that we're properly segmenting a different workloads within the public cloud environment so that we
only allow legitimate traffic to be moving laterally within that environment the diagram you know shows one typical
example of how to do this it's called the transit VPC scenario but it basically forces all lateral traffic
within your AWS environment to go through another BPC that includes your
your firewalls or network security so that all of your lateral traffic is inspected as it's trying to move across
that way we can allow the good traffic to move but block any or detect any bad traffic and we want to do this not just
with a sort of basic layer 2/3 type of firewalling but do this based very
fine-grain on things like users applications and data in other words we want to do it at a layer 7 level where
you know we are we are really properly letting only the right traffic move
across and when you do that heavy layer 7 inspection it's a lot more compute
intensive so you need a lot more increased security capacity and throughput to handle all of that
so-called east-west traffic and finally the third S stands for a single pane of
glass for your visibility and control so as we migrate we're close to the public
cloud we still in most cases are maintaining a on premise data center or a private cloud and we want to be able
to ensure that we have a single pane of glass for our policies and
our security events as they're coming in across both the private and the public across that entire hybrid cloud so that
we can we can understand everything from from as a single security posture and ideally we'd like to have consistent
security rules and policies across this entire hybrid cloud so it shouldn't matter what what rules are applied to a
certain workload depending on whether it's in the private public cloud it shouldn't really matter so that way if you're doing that migration you know
that that workload has the same security posture both before and after the fact so so it kind of summarizes the 3 s's
